entry.title: Sorting a pageBlockTable
entry.content:
Continuing on the pageBlockTable one of the features I frequently need is the ability to sort a pageBlockTable. Now there must be millions of possible ways to go about that but today I’ll show you one of mine. It’s going to be completely standard conform using only Visualforce and Apex.

Apex Code, sorting method

Apex allows you to sort on lists so that’s good to know before you start trying and implementing your custom sort functionality in apex. Lists are good if you have a list of strings or numbers but it won’t work well with a list of sobjects. That’s the reason I went with creating a list of all values in the field we want to sort and use this list as reference for my list of accounts.

public class SortingController
{
  // The list of all our accounts has a custom getter to sort immediately
  public List<Account> accounts { get {
    return sortList(accounts);
  } set; }
  // The string containing the column to filter by
  public String sortBy { get; set; }
  // The string containing the direction (ASC, DESC)
  public String sortDir { get; set; }

  // In the constructor we just define an initial list of accounts
  public SortingController()
  {
    accounts = [Select Id, Name, Site, BillingState, Phone, Type From Account];
  }

  public PageReference empty() { return null; }

  // The sorting function works on all SObjects sorting on all fields
  private List<SObject> sortList(List<SObject> cleanList)
  {
    // return the clean list if we don't have a sort field defined
    if (sortBy == null) { return cleanList; }

    // create an empty result List
    List<SObject> resultList = new List<SObject>();
    // and an object map which will be sorted
    Map<Object, List<SObject>> objectMap = new Map<Object, List<SObject>>();

    // now loop through the clean list and create the object map
    for (SObject item : cleanList) {
      if (objectMap.get(item.get(sortBy)) == null) {
        objectMap.put(item.get(sortBy), new List<SObject>());
      }
      objectMap.get(item.get(sortBy)).add(item);
    }

    // get all the keys from the object map and sort them
    List<Object> keys = new List<Object>(objectMap.keySet());
    keys.sort();

    // now create a result list by adding all objects from the object map
    // in the sorted order
    for(Object key : keys) {
      resultList.addAll(objectMap.get(key));
    }

    // clear the clean list
    cleanList.clear();
    // depending on the direction add the items in the correct sorting to the clean list
    if (sortDir == 'ASC') {
      for (SObject item : resultList) {
        cleanList.add(item);
      }
    } else {
      for (Integer i = resultList.size()-1; i >= 0; i--) {
        cleanList.add(resultList[i]);
      }
    }
  
    // return the clean and now sorted list
    return cleanList;
  }
}

As you can see it’s pretty straight forward and you can implement this function in any controller or standard controller extension as long as you use a list of SObjects and have the sortBy and sortDir defined you’ll be able to sort your list with this method.

Visualforce sorting columns

Moving on to the Visualforce part of this tutorial. It’s not complicated at all, all you want to do is using a link as header and, depending on which direction you sort, show the up or the down arrow. Now the column header would look like this:

<apex:facet name="header" >
  <!-- we are using an empty page reference here -->
  <apex:commandLink action="{!empty}">
    <!-- show the label of the columns field -->
    <apex:outputText value="{!$ObjectType.Account.Fields.Name.Label}" />
    <!-- if we wort by this column in ascending direction show this image -->
    <apex:outputText escape="false" rendered="{!sortBy=='Name'&&sortDir=='ASC'}">
      <img src="http://stachl.me/s.gif" alt="Sorted Ascending" class="sortAsc" title="Sorted Ascending" />
    </apex:outputText>
    <!-- and of course the other way around -->
    <apex:outputText escape="false" rendered="{!sortBy=='Name'&&sortDir=='DESC'}">
      <img src="http://stachl.me/s.gif" alt="Sorted Descending" class="sortDesc" title="Sorted Descending" />
    </apex:outputText>
    <!-- define the two parameters with the value for the link -->
    <apex:param value="Name" name="column" assignTo="{!sortBy}" />
    <apex:param value="{!IF(sortDir=='ASC'&&sortBy=='Name', 'DESC', 'ASC')}" name="direction" assignTo="{!sortDir}" />
  </apex:commandLink>
</apex:facet>

It’s definitely more to write as if you’d only show the name of the column but well once you have written it once you can copy paste it and only change the field name everywhere. But for all the lazy folks like me here is the complete page too.

<apex:page controller="SortingController" >
  <apex:sectionHeader title="Accounts" subtitle="Sorting Example" />
  <apex:form >

	    <apex:pageBlockTable value="{!accounts}" var="account" >

              </apex:outputText>
              <apex:outputText escape="false" rendered="{!sortBy=='Site'&&sortDir=='DESC'}">
                <img src="http://stachl.me/s.gif" alt="Sorted Descending" class="sortDesc" title="Sorted Descending" />
              </apex:outputText>

          </apex:facet>
          <apex:outputText value="{!account.Site}" />
        </apex:column>
        <apex:column >
          <apex:facet name="header" >
            <apex:commandLink action="{!empty}">
              <apex:outputText value="{!$ObjectType.Account.Fields.BillingState.Label}" />
              <apex:outputText escape="false" rendered="{!sortBy=='BillingState'&&sortDir=='ASC'}">
                <img src="http://stachl.me/s.gif" alt="Sorted Ascending" class="sortAsc" title="Sorted Ascending" />
              </apex:outputText>
              <apex:outputText escape="false" rendered="{!sortBy=='BillingState'&&sortDir=='DESC'}">
                <img src="http://stachl.me/s.gif" alt="Sorted Descending" class="sortDesc" title="Sorted Descending" />
              </apex:outputText>
              <apex:param value="BillingState" name="column" assignTo="{!sortBy}" />

              <apex:outputText escape="false" rendered="{!sortBy=='Phone'&&sortDir=='ASC'}">
                <img src="http://stachl.me/s.gif" alt="Sorted Ascending" class="sortAsc" title="Sorted Ascending" />
              </apex:outputText>
              <apex:outputText escape="false" rendered="{!sortBy=='Phone'&&sortDir=='DESC'}">

              </apex:outputText>
              <apex:param value="Phone" name="column" assignTo="{!sortBy}" />
              <apex:param value="{!IF(sortDir=='ASC'&&sortBy=='Phone', 'DESC', 'ASC')}" name="direction" assignTo="{!sortDir}" />
            </apex:commandLink>
          </apex:facet>
          <apex:outputText value="{!account.Phone}" />
        </apex:column>
        <apex:column >
          <apex:facet name="header" >
            <apex:commandLink action="{!empty}">
              <apex:outputText value="{!$ObjectType.Account.Fields.Type.Label}" />
              <apex:outputText escape="false" rendered="{!sortBy=='Type'&&sortDir=='ASC'}">
                <img src="http://stachl.me/s.gif" alt="Sorted Ascending" class="sortAsc" title="Sorted Ascending" />
              </apex:outputText>
              <apex:outputText escape="false" rendered="{!sortBy=='Type'&&sortDir=='DESC'}">
                <img src="http://stachl.me/s.gif" alt="Sorted Descending" class="sortDesc" title="Sorted Descending" />
              </apex:outputText>
              <apex:param value="Type" name="column" assignTo="{!sortBy}" />
              <apex:param value="{!IF(sortDir=='ASC'&&sortBy=='Type', 'DESC', 'ASC')}" name="direction" assignTo="{!sortDir}" />
            </apex:commandLink>
          </apex:facet>
          <apex:outputText value="{!account.Type}" />
        </apex:column>
	    </apex:pageBlockTable>
	  </apex:pageBlock>
  </apex:form>
</apex:page>

Now as you see it’s really simple to implement sorting on columns in a pageBlockTable. If you have questions or ideas, you know the drill.

entry.title: PageBlockTable Detail Row
entry.content:
Have you ever been in the situation where you needed an additional row as detail view in a table? Visualforce allows for a really simple solution to this problem and in this post I’ll try to give a high level view on how you can do that. Most of you probably will be satisfied if I tell you it’s done with the attribute breakBefore on the apex:column. So check out the documentation and get rolling on it: apex:column - Visualforce - Documentation

For all of you who need a little bit more information here we go …

The Visualforce Page

I’ll just assume you’ll have a controller set up with all the information you need for your table so let’s jump right into how we would build the pageBlockTable. For this example I’ll use a standard controller so I don’t need to set up any additional data.

<apex:page standardController="Account" >
  <apex:pageBlock title="My Contacts" >
    <apex:pageBlockTable value="{!Account.Contacts}" var="Contact" >
      <apex:column >
        <apex:facet name="header">Contact Name</apex:facet>
        <apex:outputLink value="/{!Contact.Id}" >
          <apex:outputText value="{!Contact.FirstName} {!Contact.LastName}" />
        </apex:outputLink>
      </apex:column>
      <apex:column >
        <apex:facet name="header">Title</apex:facet>
        <apex:outputText value="{!Contact.Title}" />
      </apex:column>
      <apex:column >
        <apex:facet name="header">Email</apex:facet>
        <apex:outputText value="{!Contact.Email}" />
      </apex:column>
      <apex:column >
        <apex:facet name="header">Phone</apex:facet>
        <apex:outputText value="{!Contact.Phone}" />
      </apex:column>
      <!-- This is our detail view -->
      <apex:column breakBefore="true" colspan="4" >
        <apex:outputText value="{!Contact.MailingStreet}" /><br />
        <apex:outputText value="{!Contact.MailingPostalCode}" /> <apex:outputText value="{!Contact.MailingCity}" /><br />
        <apex:outputText value="{!Contact.MailingState}" /> <apex:outputText value="{!Contact.MailingCountry}" />
      </apex:column>
    </apex:pageBlockTable>
  </apex:pageBlock>
</apex:page>

Now sometimes you don’t have a detail view for each row, in these cases you can set the rendered attribute on the detail apex:column. You can also give it a class name and add some javascript to make the detail view collapsible.

Screenshot

If you want more information on that or a detailed tutorial just leave a comment and I’ll get back to you as soon as possible.

entry.title: Ideas knocked out
entry.content:
As promised in my post on Sep. 4th Knockout.js for Visualforce today we are revisiting Knockout.js. The project we are going to build is an ideas portal and we will be using sites to publish it. This portal will have two states, the public state in which all visitors can view the ideas, see the points, read the comments and change the community. In the second state, the logged in state, users will be able to promote and demote ideas, leave comments and even add new ideas to the selected community.

Information: I’m not going to build out the portal completely, but this tutorial will show you how you could build out a portal and if you invest a few more hours you might have a fully functioning ideas community on Facebook.

The models

For this to work we will be using three SObjects - Idea, IdeaComment and Vote. So let’s start out in creating javascript models for those objects.

function Idea(options) {
  if (options == null) options = {};
  var _this = this;
  this.id = options.Id || '';
  this.community = options.CommunityId || '';
  this.author = options.CreatedBy && options.CreatedBy.Name ? options.CreatedBy.Name : '';
  this.created = Date.parse(options.CreatedDate) || Date.now();
  this.title = ko.observable(options.Title || '');
  this.body = ko.observable(options.Body || '');
  this.votes = ko.observableArray([]);
  this.comments = ko.observableArray([]);
  
  if (options.Votes && options.Votes.records) {
    ko.utils.arrayForEach(options.Votes.records, function(vote) {
      _this.votes().push(new Vote(vote));
    });
  }
  
  if (options.Comments && options.Comments.records) {
    ko.utils.arrayForEach(options.Comments.records, function(comment) {
      _this.comments().push(new Comment(comment));
    });
  }
  
  this.summary = ko.computed(function() {
    var str = this.body().replace(/(<([^>]+)>)/ig, '');
    return str.length < 300 ? str : str.substr(0, str.lastIndexOf(' ', 297)) + '...';
  }, this)
  
  this.score = ko.computed(function() {
    var score = 0;
    ko.utils.arrayForEach(this.votes(), function(vote) {
      vote.type === 'Up' ? score += 10 : score -= 10
    });
    return score;
  }, this);
  
  this.can_vote = ko.computed(function() {
    return !ko.utils.arrayFirst(this.votes(), function(vote) { return vote.author_id === user.id });
  }, this);
  
  this.promote = function(idea) {
    if (!user.logged_in) {
      return $('#not-logged-in').modal('show');
    }

    if (idea.can_vote()) {
      vote = new Vote({
        ParentId: idea.id,
        Type: 'Up',
        CreatedById: user.id
      });
      idea.votes().push(vote.save());
    }
  };
  
  this.demote = function(idea) {
    if (!user.logged_in) {
      return $('#not-logged-in').modal('show');
    }

    if (idea.can_vote()) {
      vote = new Vote({
        ParentId: idea.id,
        Type: 'Down',
        CreatedById: user.id
      });
      idea.votes().push(vote.save());
    }
  };
  
  this.save = function(idea) {
    if (!user.logged_in) {
      return $('#not-logged-in').modal('show');
    }

    var sobj = new sforce.SObject('Idea');
    sobj.Title = idea.title();
    sobj.Body = idea.body();
    sobj.CommunityId = idea.community || view_model.community;

    var result = sforce.connection.create([sobj]);

    sobj.Id = result[0].id;
    sobj.CreatedBy = {
      Name: user.fullname
    };

    idea = new Idea(sobj);
    idea.promote(idea);

    view_model.latest_ideas.unshift(idea);
  };
  
  this.show = function(idea) {
    view_model.idea(idea);
    $('#index').hide();
    $('#show').show();
  };
  
  this.index = function() {
    $('#show').hide();
    $('#index').show();
  };
}

As you can see this is our biggest model, it handles a lot of stuff for us. Like for example it holds all our comments and votes, it can be promoted and demoted and it even changes our view. I know the latter should probably be in a controller but Knockout.js is a MVVM framework which stands for Model-View-View Model so we don’t really have controllers. But you can definitely come up with something if you need a controller.

Let’s move on to our other two SObject models:

function Comment(options) {
  if (options == null) options = {};
   this.id = options.Id || '';
   this.author = options.CreatedBy && options.CreatedBy.Name ? options.CreatedBy.Name : '';
   this.created = Date.parse(options.CreatedDate) || Date.now();
   this.idea_id = options.IdeaId || '';
   this.body = ko.observable(options.CommentBody || '');
   
   this.save = function(comment) {
    if (!user.logged_in) {
      return $('#not-logged-in').modal('show');
    }

    var sobj = new sforce.SObject('IdeaComment');
    sobj.CommentBody = comment.body();
    sobj.IdeaId = view_model.idea().id;

    var result = sforce.connection.create([sobj]);

    sobj.Id = result[0].id;
    sobj.CreatedBy = {
      Name: user.fullname
    };

    sobj = new Comment(sobj);

    view_model.idea().comments.unshift(sobj);
    view_model.latest_comments.unshift(sobj);
    comment.reset(comment);
  };
  
  this.reset = function(comment) {
     view_model.comment(new Comment());
  };
}

The comment model is actually pretty straight forward, we have the set_options method to setup the comment, of course a save method and the reset method which resets the comment on the view-model so we can create another one.

For the last SObject the code is even simpler:

function Vote(options) {
  if (options == null) {
    options = {};
  }
  this.id = options.Id || '';
  this.idea_id = options.ParentId || '';
  this.type = options.Type || '';
  this.author_id = options.CreatedById || '';
  
  this.save = function() {
    var result, sobj;
    sobj = new sforce.SObject('Vote');
    sobj.ParentId = this.idea_id;
    sobj.Type = this.type;
    result = sforce.connection.create([sobj]);
    return this.id = result[0].id;
  };
}

The View-Model

After creating all those models we need a View-Model, that’s basically a model which contains all our template bindings. It’ll also manage general stuff like authentication, hold the user information and show the new idea modal and coordinate the Facebook integration.

view_model = {
  popular_ideas: ko.observableArray([]),
  latest_ideas: ko.observableArray([]),
  latest_comments: ko.observableArray([]),
  idea: ko.observable({}),
  comment: ko.observable({}),
  community: '{!community_id}',
  facebook: {
    appId: 'YourFacebookAppId',
    status: true,
    cookie: true
  },
  setup_facebook: function() {
    FB.init(view_model.facebook);

    if (window.self != window.top) {
      $('html, body').css('overflow', 'hidden');
      FB.Canvas.setAutoGrow();
    } else {
      location.replace('https://www.facebook.com/pages/Stachl-Testing-Page/159957404030861?sk=app_241179819338794');
    }

    FB.getLoginStatus(function(rsp) {
      if (rsp.status == 'connected') {
        user.facebook = {
          logged_in: true,
          uid: rsp.authResponse.userID,
          access_token: rsp.authResponse.accessToken
        };
      }
    });
  },
  login: function() {
    if (typeof fbookLoginRedirector == 'function') {
      fbookLoginRedirector();
    }
  },
  add_to_page: function() {
    FB.ui({
      method: 'pagetab',
      redirect_url: location.href
    });
  },
  new_idea: function() {
    if (!user.logged_in) {
      return $('#not-logged-in').modal('show');
    }

    view_model.idea(new Idea({
      CommunityId: view_model.community
    }));

    $('#new-idea').modal('show');
  }
};

// after setting the view_model up we also need to add some data and initialize the bindings
view_model.idea(new Idea());
view_model.comment(new Comment());
// fetches popular ideas and maps them to our ideas
view_model.popular_ideas(ko.utils.arrayMap({!popularIdeas}, function(idea) {
  return new Idea(idea);
}));
// same goes for latest ideas
view_model.latest_ideas(ko.utils.arrayMap({!latestIdeas}, function(idea) {
  return new Idea(idea);
}));
// and latest comments
view_model.latest_comments(ko.utils.arrayMap({!latestComments}, function(comment) {
  return new Comment(comment);
}));

// initializing facebook
view_model.setup_facebook();

// and apply bindings
ko.applyBindings(view_model);

General stuff

As we are using the Salesforce Javascript Toolkit for authenticated interactions between Salesforce and the user we’ll need to set the session id. Besides the sessionId for the ajax toolkit we also use the variable user a lot, so here is the code for both:

sforce.connection.sessionId = '{!GETSESSIONID()}'

user = {
  // visualforce function to check if we are logged in or not
  logged_in: {!IF(NOT(CONTAINS($User.LastName, 'Site Guest User')), 'true', 'false')},
  // get the current users id
  id: '{!$User.Id}',
  // and of course the name
  fullname: '{!$User.FirstName} {!$User.LastName}',
  // if we want to use facebook interactions we'll also need the facebook authentication
  facebook: {
    logged_in: false,
    uid: null,
    access_token: null
  }
};

One last thing I almost forgot, we will be working with a date string in the view. Now Knockoutjs doesn’t support date bindings out of the box so we need to write an addition to it:

ko.bindingHandlers.dateString = {
  update: function(element, valueAccessor, allBindingsAccessor, viewModel) {
    var value = valueAccessor()
    var allBindings = allBindingsAccessor()

    var valueUnwrapped = ko.utils.unwrapObservable(value)
    var pattern = allBindings.datePattern || 'dd.MM.yyyy'
    $(element).text(valueUnwrapped.toString(pattern))
  }
};

That’s for the javascript part of the application. As you can see we are also using a few apex variables. That’s basically to allow guests (guest’s can’t use the API) and have some initial data to display as soon as the page gets loaded. The apex part is very small compared to the javascript part …

public class IdeaController
{

  private final String field_query = 'Body, CommunityId, Id, CreatedBy.Name, CreatedDate, Title';
  private final String vote_query = 'Select Id, ParentId, Type, CreatedById From Votes';
  private final String comment_query = 'Select Id, CommentBody, CreatedBy.Name, CreatedDate, IdeaId From Comments Order By CreatedDate Desc';
  private final ApexPages.StandardSetController ideaSetController;
  
  public String community_id { get; set; }
  public String title { get; set; }
  
  public IdeaSetExtension(ApexPages.StandardSetController controller)
  {
    community_id = '09aE0000000PBPA';
    title = 'My Community';
    ideaSetController = (ApexPages.StandardSetController)controller;
  }

  public String getPopularIdeas()
  {
    List<Idea> ideas = Database.query('Select ' + field_query + ', (' + vote_query + '), (' + comment_query + ') From Idea Where CommunityId = \'' + community_id + '\' Order By VoteScore Desc Limit 3');
    return JSON.serialize(ideas);
  }

  public String getLatestIdeas()
  {
    List<Idea> ideas = Database.query('Select ' + field_query + ', (' + vote_query + '), (' + comment_query + ') From Idea Where CommunityId = \'' + community_id + '\' Order By CreatedDate Desc Limit 3');
    return JSON.serialize(ideas);
  }

  public String getLatestComments()
  {
    List<IdeaComment> comments = Database.query('Select CommentBody, CreatedBy.Name, CreatedDate, IdeaId From IdeaComment Where IdeaId In (Select Id From Idea Where CommunityId = \'' + community_id + '\') Order By CreatedDate Desc Limit 3');
    return JSON.serialize(comments);
  }
}

Templates and HTML

I’m not going to explain the templates most of it is plain HTML and as you can see bindings are set up by using the data attribute data-bind. On the bottom of the template you can also see that templates within templates are possible, I used them for loops but it’s not mandatory.

<!-- Container -->
<div class="container-fluid">
  <ul class="nav nav-tabs">
    <li class="active"><a href="{!URLFOR($Page.ideas_home)}">My Community</a></li>
    <li class="pull-right"><a href="#" data-bind="click: new_idea"><i class="icon-edit"></i> New Idea</a></li>
  </ul>
  <div id="index">
    <div class="row-fluid">
      <div class="span12 well">
        <h2>Popular Ideas</h2>
      </div>
    </div>
    <div class="template" data-bind="template: { name: 'idea-template', foreach: popular_ideas }"></div>
    <div class="row-fluid">
      <div class="span12 well">
        <h2>Latest Ideas</h2>
      </div>
    </div>
    <div class="template" data-bind="template: { name: 'idea-template', foreach: latest_ideas }"></div>
    <div class="row-fluid">
      <div class="span12 well">
        <h2>Latest Comments</h2>

entry.title: Salesforce Site and Facebook Page Tab
entry.content:
Every once in a while in my job I get asked to develop an application on the Force.com Platform that can be included into a Facebook Page as a page tab. Now initially you’d think not a problem at all we’ll just create visualforce page and put it on a site, link the Facebook page tab app to the visualforce page and that’s it. We’ll you’re right it would be really that simple if you don’t need the Facebook user to sign in and be an authenticated portal user on the site.

But authentication can’t be to terrible since Spring ‘12 Salesforce even offers the so called Social Single Sign On which allows you to add Facebook as an authentication provider in your Salesforce Organization. Still it’s not the simplest of all tasks, with all those redirections, X-Frame and SSL policies and what not. So after the third time I tried to hack my way around I thought why not come up with a flow that works always and package it up for reuse.

My solution involved a redirection flow built in Javascript and packaged as a visualforce Component. So here is what basically happens:

  • John Doe finds himself on our Facebook Page
  • He clicks on the page tab
  • Depending on weather John surfs using SSL or not the page tab loads the visualforce page using the same protocol
  • Now the first thing this script does is to test if John Doe has a valid session
  • John Doe has never been on our visualforce page so he is redirected to the SSSO
  • The SSSO in turn will redirect John back to Facebook so he can authenticate and authorize our app
  • If he does he’ll then get redirected back to SSSO which will either create a new user or use an existing one for John
  • SSSO knows that the request came from a Force.com Site and redirects accordingly
  • At this stage the script will check if there is a return URL set and redirect there

Now all you need to do is grab the code for the component on github.com/tstachl and add it to your probably empty start/redirector page: <c:fbookLoginRedirector loginUrl="" retUrl="" /> There is an example visualforce page included and if you set this page as start page of a site you should be good to go.

entry.title: Another turning point
entry.content:
Eventually everyone has to decide whether to live his life according to a predefined course or to take action and pursuit a life of happiness and joy but also downfalls and hardship. Are you walking the safe road or are you choosing a live of adventure and unknown? For me it was a very personal decision I made two years ago - I started to live my life in the pursuit of my dreams.

You can probably ask every person who spent time with me and they’ll all tell you that my dream is and was to live in the United States. But two years ago when I started this journey I had to make sure that it really was what I wanted for myself, so I decided to quit my job and become a freelancer.

As a freelancer you have certain privileges, like working from wherever and whenever you want. You can decide to work 4 hours a day or 12 hours, it’s up to you to find a company to work for or projects to work on. So that was a perfect fit for my US trial run. I started to work for a San Francisco based company developing web services.

A few months in I was able to afford my first trip to Los Angeles so I bought my tickets and even had a few hundred dollars left on my bank account for incidentals. It was around the 15th of June 2010 and I still remember as if it was yesterday. My mom gave me a ride to the airport in Munich and I took off. After a quick flight to London and a brief overlay I boarded a big Boing which should take me all the way over the Atlantic ocean to the Pacific.

It must have been around 7pm when I finally arrived and I got into the bus to Union Station where I was supposed to meet a guy I met on CouchSurfing.org - but he never showed. Something must have happened, I thought. While still whishing for the best I found myself a cab and gave the drive the address.

Even though I had this feeling of uncertainty in my stomach I was so overwhelmed by all those new impressions, the smell, the dry LA heat in the evenings I didn’t even think about loosing faith. And as it turned out I was right, he just forgot about my arrival time so I still had a bed for the first few nights.

Cutting a really long story short - I had the best time in Los Angeles and even after three months of not seeing my family and friends back home in Austria, I still wouldn’t want to leave. This showed me that I was on the right track. That I should reach for the stars and continue my quest.

Jumping ahead to June 2011 the 6th to be exact. Once again I found myself at the airport in Munich saying my goodbyes to my mother and Josef. This time it wasn’t about going to the US, I started a job with Salesforce.com in their European headquarters in Dublin, Ireland. Salesforce is also a San Francisco based company, one of the first to use the term cloud computing. As opposed to being a freelancer this gainful employment was always meant to be my stepping stone to the States.

In those almost one and a half years I found myself growing fond of Ireland, Dublin especially as I actually didn’t see much more than that. And with Salesforce I was even able to fly over to San Francisco twice, I also got the opportunity to visit London and had an extended stay with our neighbors in Munich. Telling you all this and giving a slight hint to Forbes list of best companies to work for should be enough to convince you that I never regret for one second haven take up this nine-to-five.

And it’s about to get even better, over the course of the last couple of months I applied for a position as a Technical Consultant with a 100 % subsidiary of Salesforce in San Francisco. Yes you read correctly, one of my dreams is about to come true and I’ll be able to live and work in one of the most accomplished nations of this world. I’m going to work for Desk.com.

A new part of my life is starting in a few weeks and once again I’m overcome with joy and happiness but also the knowledge that it doesn’t end here. Dreams are coming every night like clockwork, I close my eyes and start imagining and everything begins again. What’s next? I don’t know but one thing I know for sure, it’s going to be one hell of ride.

entry.title: Knockout.js for Visualforce
entry.content:
Last week I saw an introduction video about Knockout.js a javascript library that shows sweet advantages on declarative bindings, automatic UI refresh, dependency tracking and templating.

After watching this I realized how nice and easy you could bind data onto forms, tables and whole templates. Immediately I thought about Visualforce and how this could make it easier to create nice looking custom user interfaces utilizing either Apex remote action or the Javascript toolkit.

My colleague a big jQuery fan didn’t seem to be convinced at all, so the challenge was set and I knew what I had to do.

The Challenge

For the first try run I wanted to find something simple and an editable grid showing accounts (Twitter handles of accounts to be more precise) seemed to be easy enough. The idea was to show the list of accounts with account name, a disabled checkbox to indicate whether or not an account had a Twitter handle and of course the Twitter handle itself which should be editable.

The fun part

So I started out with creating a Visualforce page and a controller. The only reason for the controller was to get a JSON encoded list of accounts and I thought that was a fast and straight forward approach, whilst the real magic is happening in the Visualforce page. At least in this small example. So let’s start with the controller:

public class KnockoutController
{
  public KnockoutController()
  {}
  public String getAccountsJson()
  {
    return JSON.serialize((List<Account>)[SELECT Id, Name, TwitterHandle__c FROM Account]);
  }
}

As you can see there is one getter for the account list and that’s it. The Visualforce page on the other hand contains 64 lines of markup and code. I think most of it is self explanatory but I added a few comments just in case.

<apex:page controller="KnockoutController" tabStyle="Account" >
  <apex:includeScript value="https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/knockout/2.1.0/knockout-min.js" />
  <apex:sectionHeader title="Knockout.js + Salesforce.com" subtitle="Like?" />
  
  <!-- The Template -->
  <table width="100%">
    <thead>
      <tr>
        <th>Account Name</th>
        <th>Has Twitter</th>
        <th>Twitter Handle</th>
      </tr>
    </thead>
    <tbody data-bind="foreach: accounts">
      <tr>
        <td data-bind="text: name"></td>
        <td>
          <input type="checkbox" disabled="disabled" data-bind="checked: has_twitter" />
        </td>
        <td data-bind="event: { dblclick: toggle_edit }">
          <span data-bind="visible: !is_editing(), text: twitter"></span>
          <input data-bind="visible: is_editing, value: twitter, event: { blur: toggle_edit }" />
        </td>
      </tr>
    </tbody>
  </table>

  <script>
    !function() {
      // The Account model
      function Account(options) {
        this.id = options.Id || ''
        this.name = options.Name || ''
        this.twitter = ko.observable(options.TwitterHandle__c || '')
        this.is_editing = ko.observable(false)
        
        // computed observable tells us if we have a twitter handle
        this.has_twitter = ko.computed(function() {
          return !!this.twitter()
        }, this)

        // the function to toggle between editing and viewing
        this.toggle_edit = function(account) {
          account.is_editing(!account.is_editing())
        }
      }

      // all of the magic happens in the model
      // the viewModel just holds the accounts array
      view_model = {
        accounts: ko.observableArray([])
      }

      // here we have our {!accountsJson} mapped and transformed to
      // account objects
      view_model.accounts(ko.utils.arrayMap({!accountsJson}, function(account) {
        return new Account(account)
      }))

      // last but not least we need to apply all bindings
      ko.applyBindings(view_model)
    }()
  </script>
</apex:page>

Conclusion

As you can see it’s fairly simple to create a nice observable and dynamic user interface using Knockout.js. Even-though my colleague would still tell me it’s faster to build this functionality in jQuery (and he might even be right), this weekend I’m going to show you why I consider Knockout.js a really good idea and how fast and straight forward you can create a nice and clean Salesforce Ideas clone.

entry.title: Jekyll Kramdown and PrittyPrint
entry.content:
Jekyll ships with a markdown converter called Maruku, as you can see in the github repo it’s 2 years since the last update on this library happend. That’s pretty much how it behaves. At first I tried to monkey patch it and add capabilities to add classes onto elements. That didn’t go over well so I tried to fetch the output before it get’s written in the file and replace the <pre> tags with <pre class="prittyprint">. That worked pretty well until I wanted to use different languages, even though Googles PrettyPrint seems to come with an auto language lookup that didn’t work that good.

And all I wanted was being able to add stupid class attributes on elements, is that too much to ask?

No! Finally I discovered in the source code of jekyll that I could use another engine to render markdown. Well I kind of saw it before but at this point I was desperate so I looked up the documentation on RedCarpet, probably a really good engine. Well you guessed it there is a but coming … But RedCarpet didn’t work on the fly and needed additional monkey patches to work properly. So another nogo for me.

Kramdown is coming

Kramdown is another markdown render engine for Ruby and it’s supported by jekyll what a rush. The good thing about it is, it supports everything I need and probably way more, I installed it and it worked!

Here is how …

Installing Kramdown

The first thing we want to do is revisit our Gemfile from the first post when we installed Jekyll on Heroku. All we need to do is add this line:

source :rubygems

gem 'rake'
gem 'kramdown'        # add this line to get kramdown installed
[ ... ]

Now call the bundler to install kramdown:

$ cd my_blog
$ bundle package && bundle install

Next we need to make sure kramdown is used by jekyll to render markdown, this is done by setting kramdown as markdown engine within the _config.yml file.

[ ... ]
auto: true
pygments: true
markdown: kramdown    # add this line make jekyll use kramdown
[ ... ]

That’s basically it. All you have to do now is read up on the documentation and you are all set to use the highlighter. No wait, first of all I didn’t tell you how to add Google PrettyPrint and then you might also want to know what you have to write in your .md documents to add the class needed by Google PrettyPrint.

Installing Google PrettyPrint

Regarding the js and css file for PrettyPrint, I have no idea what to tell you - I pretty much stole them directly from the Twitter Bootstrap documentation page:

<head>
  <link href="http://twitter.github.com/bootstrap/assets/js/google-code-prettify/prettify.css" rel="stylesheet">
  <script src="http://twitter.github.com/bootstrap/assets/js/google-code-prettify/prettify.js"></script>
  <script>
    // make sure jQuery is loaded before you run this function,
    // probably a good idea to create an application.js loaded
    // as last js file
    $(function() {
      // make code pritty
      window.prettyPrint && prettyPrint();
    });
  </script>
</head>

My suggestion, download those files and store them in your assets folder. In your _layouts/default.html you’d simply link them with {{ ASSET_PATH }} to where ever you put them.

Now to the fun part, adding prettyprint lang-html linenums to your code snippets in markdown, ahhm kramdown:

{:.prettyprint .linenums .lang-ruby}
    def hello_world(name)
      "Hello #{name}!"
    end

You are all set! If you need more information or help or if you simply love this post or you have critisism just leave a comment in the section below.

entry.title: Jekyll Bootstrap Filters
entry.content:
The blog engine Jekyll runs with the templating engine Liquid, an extraction from the e-commerce system Shopify. It has been in production since 2006 and was initially developed for Ruby on Rails web applications.

Liquid offers a lot of built in functionality but sometimes you want customized methods to fit your needs. The extendability with filters, tags, generators and converters comes in handy in these situations. Now this post won’t cover all of those but the former we’ll tackle today.

Liquid Filters

Filters are basically methods that change input in customized way and the most important aspect on filters is, that you can apply as many filters as you want on a variable. Here is an example:

Hello {{ user.name | linkify: user.website }}
Hello {{ user.name | append: '*' | prepend: '*' | textilize | upcase }}

28 - that’s the number of filters that are delivered to your door with Liquid, some of them more useful than others ({{ 10 | divided_by: 2 }} #=> 5) but for the most part nothing missing. Sure there are some cases, like using Bootstrap, in which you could use some more filters but that’s what we are here for, right?

So let’s get started then …

Creating bootstrap.rb

First we have to locate or create the plugin folder within the jekyll installation folder:

$ cd ~/my_jekyll_blog
$ ls -l
total 144
-rw-r--r--   1 tstachl  454177323     34 May 26 22:47 404.html
[ ... ]
drwxr-xr-x   3 tstachl  454177323    102 May 26 22:47 _plugins
[ ... ]

As you can see mine already exists but if yours doesn’t simply create one with the following command:

$ mkdir _plugins

Now in this folder we have to create a new file called boostrap.rb. This file is going to contain all our bootstrap related plugins. Let’s start off by creating a module Bootstrap that’s wrapping a module Filters and of course the register filter method like this:

module Bootstrap
  module Filters
    
  end
end

Liquid::Template.register_filter(Bootstrap::Filters)

The first filter we want to create is a label filter so we don’t have to write <span class="label">My Label</span> but instead we write {{ 'My Label' | label }}. To accomplish that we create a new method within the Filters module:

def label(input)
  "<span class='label'>#{input}</span>"
end

That’s it! Save the file, start jekyll and create a new post/page using the label filter.

Want more?

Granted bootstrap has more than the default label, like success, important, info and so on. Now we could create a function for each of those:

def label_success(input)
  "<span class='label label-success'>#{input}</span>"
end

But that’s going to become annoying real soon. So let ruby create those methods for you, you know you’ll need [:success, :warning, :important, :info, :reverse] these additional functions so we create a define_method function and auto create the methods we need.

[:success, :warning, :important, :info, :reverse].each do |arg|
  send :define_method, ("label_#{arg.to_s}").to_sym do |input|
    label(input)
  end
end

As you can see we created an array with the 5 label sub categories and each of those itself is defining a method, prepending label_ onto the method name and calling the previously created label method.

That’ll work for filters like {{ 'My Label' | label_success }} now but it’ll still show up as default label because we never changed the inital label method to add another class to the list. To do that we’ll have to alter the label method:

def label(input, subcls = '')
  "<span class='label'>#{input}</span>" unless subcls.empty?
  "<span class='label label-#{subcls}'>#{input}</span>"
end

If you test the code again it should still work but you won’t see any changes, every label will still render the default label. So let’s amend our define_method function …

[:success, :warning, :important, :info, :reverse].each do |arg|
  send :define_method, ("label_#{arg.to_s}").to_sym do |input|
    label(input, arg.to_s)
  end
end

This little change is all it takes and now we can render all 5 sub categories of label without a problem.

Here is the complete file again:

module Bootstrap
  module Filters
    def label(input, subcls = '')
      "<span class='label'>#{input}</span>" unless subcls.empty?
      "<span class='label label-#{subcls}'>#{input}</span>"
    end
    
    [:success, :warning, :important, :info, :reverse].each do |arg|
      send :define_method, ("label_#{arg.to_s}").to_sym do |input|
        label(input, arg.to_s)
      end
    end
  end
end

Liquid::Template.register_filter(Bootstrap::Filters)

entry.title: Jekyll on Heroku
entry.content:
Before you start with this tutorial please make sure you have all prerequisites set up. Important: Make sure you have a working Ruby and the Gem Bundler installed. The easiest way to do that is by installing the Ruby Version Manager by following this Quick Install Guide. Next you also want to make sure you have the Heroku Toolbelt installed. If you don’t check out the Toolbelt website and follow the instructions provided. Continue this tutorial once your system is set up.

Setting up Jekyll

Get Jekyll

The best way to do that is cloning the Github repository jekyll-bootstrap, this will come with twitter boostrap included.

$ git clone https://github.com/plusjade/jekyll-bootstrap.git my_blog
$ cd my_blog

Prepare Jekyll for Heroku

Once your Jekyll is downloaded/cloned we can start to prepare for Heroku. All we need for our blog to run on Heroku are two files, both in the root folder of Jekyll:

my_blog/Gemfile
my_blog/Procfile

The first one (Gemfile) is a file for the Ruby Bundler where we define all required ruby gems for Jekyll to run on Heroku. If you need additional packages don’t hesitate to add them, this blog for example also uses the twitter-text gem to allow for nice formatted tweets on the homepage.

source :rubygems

gem "rake"                # actually not need for heroku but for the provided Rakefile
gem "RedCloth"            # if you want to use the Textile Markup Language
gem "jekyll", "~> 0.11.2" # we need at least this version so jekyll will use Ruby 1.9.2
gem "foreman"             # this is a tool to test and use the Procfile locally
gem "heroku"              # if you install the Heroku Toolbelt you won't need this but it's good practice

Now for an app to work on Heroku we need to define a Procfile. This file simply holds all information regarding processes that Heroku will have to start for an app. Using a Procfile and the cedar stack on Heroku is good for two things, one you can define any process to run and second you have total control over your processes. Not only does this allow you to run Ruby apps but you can run Scala, Python, Node.js and much more.

So if you ever get bored with Ruby (granted probably won’t happen), so if you ever want to broaden your horizon and take a sip of Node, than you simply create another app on Heroku and it’ll run.

The Procfile is an easy oneliner …

web: jekyll --server $PORT

We declare one web process with the command jekyll --server which will generate the posts and run jekyll’s built in server. The $PORT allows Heroku to assign a dynamic port for the load balancing and routing, note this has no influence locally. And that’s it. Well almost it - we also need to go into _config.yml and add those new files to the exclude list so Jekyll won’t mistake those as blog pages. Just replace the exiting list on line 5 with this:

exclude: [".rvmrc", ".rbenv-version", ".gitignore", "README.md", "Rakefile", "changelog.md", "Gemfile", "Gemfile.lock", "Procfile", "vendor"]

To make sure everything will work smoothly navigate to the directory and run bundle install to install all the gems and then foreman start which will start jekyll’s server.

$ cd my_blog
$ bundle install
$ foreman start

Once jekyll is started navigate to http://localhost:4000/ and you should see the »Hello World« of your blog.

On to Heroku

The Heroku bit of this blog post is equally as easy and consists of three commands. The first will make sure that both newly created files are added to our git repository, the second will create our app on Heroku (you’ll also get a sweet herokuapp.com subdomain) and with the third we push our app to Heroku. Heroku’ll do the rest for us as in setting up the software stack and the processes, compiling the app and launching it.

$ cd my_blog
$ git commit -am "Add and commit the Procfile and the Gemfile"
$ heroku create --stack cedar mynewblog
$ git push heroku master        
Counting objects: 689, done.
Delta compression using up to 4 threads.
Compressing objects: 100% (313/313), done.
Writing objects: 100% (689/689), 227.46 KiB | 96 KiB/s, done.
Total 689 (delta 342), reused 672 (delta 338)

-----> Heroku receiving push
-----> Ruby app detected
-----> Installing dependencies using Bundler version 1.2.0.pre
       Running: bundle install --without development:test --path vendor/bundle --binstubs bin/ --deployment
       Fetching gem metadata from http://rubygems.org/.......
       Installing rake (0.9.2.2)
